questions.text: Corpora amylacea is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Corpora amylacea (CA) are small hyaline masses of unknown significance found in the prostate gland, neuroglia, and pulmonary alveoli. They are derived from degenerate cells or thickened secretions and occur more frequently with advancing age, and are particularly profuse in neurodegenerative diseases

questions.text: Prostate calculi are usually composed of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B that is calcium Phosphate are the most common stones in salivary gland as well as prostate. Option A that is calcium oxalate is the most common type of renal calculi. Option C that is struvite is composed of triple phosphate stone composed of calcium, magnesium and aluminium phosphate. Option D that is uric acid stone is more common in patients who have high cell turnover like tumour lysis syndrome, myeloproliferative disease and others.

questions.text: Benign prostatic hyperplasia first develops in the : (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostate gland comprises of three zones: central, transitional and peripheral. BPH arises mostly from transitional zone. Ca prostate arises mostly from peripheral zone.

questions.text: In BPH most common lobe invoived is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prostate gland comprises of 5 lobes. 1 anterior, 2 lateral, 1 posterior and one median. Prostate carcinoma arises from posterior lobe. BPH arises from median lobe.

choices.text: Voiding bladder pressures > 50 cm of water

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute indication for surgery in cases of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bilateral hydronephrosis is the most common and most important indication of surgery for BPH. Option B is wrong as increased frequency per say is not an indication of surgery for BPH. Option C is wrong as size of the prostate gland is not a sole indication of surgery of BPH. Option D is wrong as voiding pressure > 80 cm of water is the indication for treatment of BOO.

questions.text: Which of the following lasers is used for treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia as well as urinary calculi?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laser which is used in the treatment of BPH as well as stones is holmium YAG laser.(Ho-YAG laser).

choices.text: It is used in the medical treatment of benign prostatic hypertrophy
Headache is well documented after its use
It blocks the conversion of dihydrotestosterone to testosterone

questions.text: The following statements regarding finasteride are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor which blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

questions.text: Grade I benign prostatic hypertrophy with outflow obstruction in best treated with: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment of choice for benign prostatic hyperplasia is transurethral resection of prostate. Options A and C are the types of open prostatectomies and are used when the size of the prostate gland is large and it is more than 75 gm in size.

questions.text: Assessment of patient with prostatism include all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) We do not do urodynamic studies, as it is invasive and may lead to UTI.

questions.text: The drug that has the fastest onset of action in benign prostatic hyperplasia is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) We have two drugs in the management of BPH. They are 5-alpha reductase inhibitors and Alpha 1 blockers. Out of these two drugs, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors have a slower onset of action and taked time to bring its effect. Its onset starts by 1 month and reaches max by 6 months. Alpha 1 blockers(tamsulosin) have a rapid onset of action and show their effect within 3-4 days.

choices.text: Systematic prostate biopsy in suspected prostate cancer
Guiding transurethral resection of prostate cancer

questions.text: The most important use of transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) is for: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct answer (C) Main aim of doing a TRUS in any patient is to take a TRUS guided biopsy. With the help of TRUS we can take 12 biopsy pieces from different areas of prostate in suspected prostate ca patients. By the use of TRUS it is very difficult to take a biopsy from the anterior lobe of prostate. Option A is false we do not use TRUS for screening of Ca prostate. We do PSA plus digital rectal examination for screening of Prostatic cancer. Option B is wrong as it can not distinguish Ca Prostate from BPH. Option D is wrong as TRUS can not help in guiding resection of prostate

questions.text: The most common complication of transurethral resection of prostate (TURP): (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common complication of TURP is retrograde ejaculation as internal urethral sphincter is damaged during TURP. Option A is wrong as erectile dysfunction is not a complication of TURP it occurs after radical prostatectomy. Option C is false as urinary incontinence can occur after TURP if external urethral sphincter is damaged but Its incidence is <1 %

questions.text: Delirium, mental confusion and nausea in patients who had undergone transurethral resection of prostate suggests: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Because of systemic absorption of the irrigant fluid into systemic circulation patients may develop “Relative Hyponatremia” which presents as delirium, mental confusion and nausea. This is because of excessive water retention and so answer is D . Option A is false as hypernatremia is not a feature after TURP. Sepsis can occur but it will present with systemic manifestations, hypotension and fever. Hepatic coma is not a feature which develops after TURP.

choices.text: Stricture of the bulb of urethra

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstructive symptoms after TURP? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstruction after TURP is bladder neck stenosis. It occurs because of prolonged surgeries which takes more than 90 minutes.

questions.text: During TURP, surgeon takes care to dissect above the verumontanum to prevent injury to: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) while operating a case of TURP it is important to prevent damage to external urethral sphincter and verumontenum acts as a landmark as external urethral sphincter lies just distal to verumontanum. If while operating a case of TURP one remains proximal to verumontenum then we can prevent injury to external urethral sphincter.

questions.text: Commonest cause of periumbilical pain after 30 min of TURP done under spinal anesthesia with Bupivacaine: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) if a patient develops periumbilical pain after 30 minutes of TURP you have to suspect perforation of bladder. Option A is wrong as meteorism is a condition in which patient develops distention of abdomen due to dilation of the intestine due to accumulation of retroperitoneal hematoma and compression of splanchnic nerves. Option C is wrong as even if the patient develops pain due to spinal anaesthesia,he will have a spinal headache or pain at the site of giving anaesthesia but not the periumbilical pain. Option D is wrong as mesenteric artery ischemia presents as a post prandial abdominal pain which is severe and does not correlate with physical findings.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is not used as an irrigant during transurethral resection of the prostate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is an isotonic solution, meaning it has a similar solute concentration to blood plasma. While isotonic solutions are generally safe for intravenous administration, they are not used as irrigants during standard monopolar TURP because they are electrically conductive. During monopolar TURP, an electric current passes through the resectoscope loop to cut and coagulate tissue. If normal saline were used, the current would be dispersed through the irrigant, leading to inefficient cutting and coagulation, and potentially damaging the surrounding tissues and the patient due to uncontrolled current spread. Additionally, the absorption of large volumes of normal saline during TURP can lead to hypernatremia (high sodium levels) and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, which are undesirable complications. B. 1.5% Glycine is incorrect. Glycine solutions (typically 1.5% or 2.2%) are commonly used as irrigants during monopolar TURP. Glycine is a non-conductive, isotonic, or slightly hypotonic solution. Its non-conductive property allows the electrical current from the resectoscope to be concentrated at the tissue, ensuring efficient cutting and coagulation. While absorption of large volumes of glycine can lead to the "TURP syndrome" (characterized by hyponatremia, fluid overload, and neurological symptoms due to hypotonic fluid absorption), its non-conductive nature makes it a primary choice for monopolar TURP. C. 5?xtrose is incorrect. 5?xtrose in water (D5W) is a hypotonic, non-conductive solution that can be used as an irrigant during TURP, though less commonly than glycine. Like glycine, its non-conductive property allows for effective energy delivery during monopolar resection. However, due to its hypotonicity, significant absorption can lead to hyponatremia and hyperglycemia, which can be problematic, especially in diabetic patients. D. Distilled water is incorrect. Distilled water is a highly hypotonic and non-conductive solution. While its non-conductive property makes it suitable for electrical current transmission during monopolar TURP, its extreme hypotonicity is a major drawback. Significant absorption of distilled water can lead to severe and rapid hemolysis (rupture of red blood cells) and profound hyponatremia, posing a significant risk of severe complications, including acute renal failure and neurological damage. For these reasons, while technically effective for current transmission, it is rarely used as an irrigant due to its high risk profile. However, the question asks which is not used, implying it's never appropriate. Compared to normal saline, which fundamentally interferes with the electrocautery, the others (though with their own risks) are considered "used" or have been used, whereas normal saline is fundamentally unsuitable for monopolar TURP.

questions.text: During TURP, while dissecting around the verumontenum, the surgeon should specifically take care to avoid Injury to which of the following? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) while operating a case of TURP it is important to prevent damage to external urethral sphincter and verumontenum acts as a landmark as external urethral sphincter lies just distal to verumontanum. If while operating a case of TURP ,one remains proximal to verumontenum then we can prevent injury to external urethral sphincter.

questions.text: Most common site of development of carcinoma of prostate is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostate gland comprises of three zones: central, transitional and peripheral. BPH arises mostly from transitional zone. Ca prostate arises mostly from peripheral zone.

questions.text: Mr. Chaturvedi, a 70 years old man comes to casualty with urinary retention retention and back pain. Which investigation should be performed? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This questions tells about an elderly person who has come to casualty with urinary retention and back pain so it points towards a patient who is suffering from prostatic carcinoma with bone metastasis . Out of all the above mentioned option the one which can give us an idea about the bony metastasis is acid phosphatase. Option B is wrong as serum calcium is a very broad test and can be altered due to many conditions. Option c Alkaline Phosphatase is helpful for biliary condition and if it is raised indicates some kind of obstruction in the biliary tract. Option D is wrong as serum electrophoresis is used for finding blood dyscrasias and not for prostatic carcinoma.

choices.text: Endorectal coil MRI with T1W and T2W images

questions.text: A 50-years old male with positive family history of prostate cancer has come to you for a screening test. The most sensitive screening test to pickup prostate cancer is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Screening for prostatic carcinoma is done for early detection and we use PSA levels and Digital rectal examination for the screening of prostatic cancer. We do not use PSA or DRE alone as when they are used together the sensitivity for detection of cancer is more. Serum PSA elevations may occur as a result of disruption of the normal prostatic architecture that allows PSA to diffuse into the prostatic tissue and gain access to the circulation. This can occur in the setting of prostate disease (BPH, prostatitis, prostate cancer) and with prostate manipulation (e.g., prostate massage, prostate biopsy, transurethral resection). PSA elevations may indicate the presence of prostate disease, but not all men with prostate disease have elevated PSA levels. Furthermore, PSA elevations are not specific for cancer. 5α-Reductase inhibitors that are used for treatment of BPH have been shown to lower PSA levels by about 50% after 12 months of treatment. Both type 2 isoenzyme inhibitors (finasteride) and dual type 1 and 2 isoenzyme inhibitors (dutasteride) lower PSA to the same extent

questions.text: Transrectal ultrasonogram in evaluation of carcinoma prostate is most useful for: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Main aim of doing a TRUS in any patient is to take a TRUS guided biopsy. With the help of TRUS we can take 12 biopsy pieces from different areas of prostate. This increases the sensitivity of diagnosis of prostatic cancer. By the use of TRUS it is very difficult to take a biopsy from the anterior lobe of prostate

questions.text: In prostatic metastasis, the site most commonly involved is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most commonly involved lymph node in prostatic metastasis is obturator nodes. First lymph node to get enlarged in prostatic and bladder cancer is obturator lymph nodes. First lymph node to be involved in testicular and renal cancer is paraaortic group of lymph nodes.

choices.text: Because valveless communication exist with bateson’s and periprostatic plexus
Via drainage to sacral lymph node

questions.text: CA prostate commonly metastases to the vertebrae:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostate is connected to perivertebral plexus of veins via a bateson plexus of veins and as these veins are valveless tumour easily spreads to vertebral areas from the prostate. .

choices.text: PSA is not produced by normal males

questions.text: Normal level of PSA in males is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PSA stands for Prostate specific antigen and is a marker of prostatic tissue. PSA < 4ng/ml is a normal value found in most of the males. PSA between 4-10 ng/ml is present in benign conditions like BPH and prostatitis and after DRE. PSA > 10 ng/ml is indicative of prostatic malignancy. PSA > 20 ng/ml is an indicator of metastatic prostatic carcinoma.

questions.text: Gleason scoring is done for: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gleason score: Is most commonly used Histological grading system for prostate cancer.

choices.text: Digital screening along with PSA is additive
Prostate cancer is common among young males
Bleeding per rectum is earliest manifestation of disease

questions.text: Which of the following is true about prostate cancer screening? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as for the screening of prostatic carcinoma we use Digital rectal examination and PSA . Both are used together as sensitivity for detection of the cancer increases as compared to when any one them is used individually. Ideally screening is started at the age of 50 years. Option B is wrong as Prostate cancer is more common in elderly patients, It is actually said that if a person lives to reach a age 80 there is 90% chance that he will have a focus of prostatic cancer. Option C is wrong as a tumour marker for Prostatic cancer is PSA and PSA is not diagnostic for prostatic cancer it is raised in many benign conditions as well. Option D is wrong as Bleeding PR is not the first manifestation of prostatic cancer.

choices.text: Higher the score, poorer the prognosis

questions.text: Gleason score: all are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gleason scores range from 2 (1 + 1 = 2), which represents tumors uniformly composed of Gleason pattern 1 tumor, to 10 (5 + 5 = 10), which represents totally undifferentiated tumors. Gleason score > 7 is considered anaplastic (High grade). Gleason score: Is most commonly used Histological grading system for prostate cancer.

questions.text: An 85 years old man underwent transuretheral resection of prostate. A histological examination of his specimen showed foci of adenocarcinoma management will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This patient describes a scenario in which a patient has undergone a TURP and carcinoma prostate has been detected in the biopsy specimen after operation. When such a scenario occurs you have to categorize the person into two groups one which includes people who are <70 years who have life expectancy more than 10 years and who are fit for surgery. In these patients we have to subject the patient for radical prostatectomy. Another group includes patients who are >70 years old and have life expectancy less than 10 years or are not fit for surgery. These patients are just subjected to observation and no further intervention is needed . As the patient in the question has age of 85 years we will just keep the patient in observation with no further treatment.

questions.text: A 70-years old man with CA prostate with osteoblastic secondaries in pelvis and lumbar vertebra showed well differentiated adeno carcinoma prostate on needle biopsy. He is ideally treated by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In this question we have a patient who has prostatic cancer and has skeletal metastasis. For skeletal metastasis there is no point in subjection the patient to radical prostatectomy therefore we go for hormonal therapy and B/L subcapsular orchidectomy for these patients.

questions.text: Management of carcinoma prostate in a 50-year old man revealed after TURP: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This patient describes a scenario in which a patient has undergone a TURP and carcinoma prostate has been detected in the biopsy specimen after operation. When such a scenario occurs you have to categorize the person into two groups one which includes people who are <70 years who have life expectancy more than 10 years and who are fit for surgery. In these patients we have to subject the patient for radical prostatectomy. Another group includes patients who are >70 years old and have life expectancy less than 10 years or are not fit for surgery. These patients are just subjected to observation and no further intervention is needed . As patient in this question is 50 year old so we have to subject the patient to radical prostatectomy. Hormonal therapy and bilateral subcapsular orchidectomy is used for metastatic prostatic cancer.

choices.text: Water intoxication and hyponatremia can give rise to CHF
Perineal prostatectomy (young) is a commonly done surgical procedure
Retrograde ejaculation occurs in about 64% of men
Intraurethral stents are helpful in the management in unfit patients.

questions.text: Regarding prostatectomy which one of the statements is false: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Perineal prostatectomy which is also called as young’s prostatectomy is a very rare operation which is undertaken now a days. Option A is correct as water intoxication and hyponatremia which develops after some cases of TURP and can even give rise to CHF. Option C is correct as retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of TURP. Option D is correct as if a patient is unfit for surgery intraurethral stents can help as a palliative treatment measure in these patients.

questions.text: Complication which commonly accompanies acute prostatitis: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Seminal vesical joins the vas deferens and forms an ejaculatory duct which opens into prostatic urethra and if the patient has prostatitis it can spread in a retrograde manner into seminal vesicle and lead to seminal vesiculitis. Epididymitis, orchitis and sterility do not commonly occur with prostatitis.

questions.text: A 60-years old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria. Patient was hospitalized in emergency for 5 days. PSA level was 7.4 next best step in this patient (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) this case scenario tells us that patient is suffering from prostatitis and we need to treat the patient conservatively with antibiotics and by admitting the patient. Option A is not the answer as even though PSA levels are raised marginally in prostatitis they are not excessively raised and even if we need to order PSA we just need it to rule out carcinoma. Option C that is TRUS guided biopsy is needed for suspected underlying prostatic carcinoma.

choices.text: Digital screening along with PSA is additive
Prostate cancer is common among young males
Bleeding per rectum is earliest manifestation of disease

questions.text: Which of the following is true about prostate cancer screening? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as for the screening of prostatic carcinoma we use Digital rectal examination and PSA . Both are used together as sensitivity for detection of the cancer increases as compared to when any one them is used individually. Ideally screening is started at the age of 50 years. Option B is wrong. Prostate cancer is more common in elderly patients, It is actually said that if a person lives to reach a age 80 there is 90% chance that he will have a focus of prostatic cancer. Option C is wrong as a tumour marker for Prostatic cancer is PSA and PSA is not diagnostic for prostatic cancer it is raised in many benign conditions as well. Option D is wrong as Bleeding PR is not the first manifestation of prostatic cancer.

questions.text: A 20-years-old man is stabbed immediately to the left of the body of the sternum at the fifth intercostal space. The knife most likely penetrated the:
questions.solution: Correct answer (D) The right ventricle comprises most of the anterior surface of the heart.
